turn.0: Hi, I'm your automated assistant. I can answer your questions about Palatal myoclonus.
turn.2: Palatal myoclonus Palatal myoclonus is a rapid spasm of the palatal (roof of the mouth) muscles, which results in clicking or popping in the ear.
turn.3: Are there any other interesting aspects about this article?
turn.4: The movements of the palate vary in rate between 40 and 200 beats per minute.
turn.5: What are the different treatment methods?
turn.6: Chronic clonus is often due to lesions of the central tegmental tract (which connects the red nucleus to the ipsilateral inferior olivary nucleus).
turn.7: Is there any other interesting information I should know?
turn.8: Uniquely, the clicking noise does not subside when the patient sleeps.
turn.9: Is there any other types of myoclonus?
turn.10: When associated with eye movements, it is known as "oculopalatal myoclonus" Signs and symptoms of Palatal Myoclonus include: Rhythmic, jerky movements in the face, eyeballs, tongue, jaw, vocal cord or extremities (mostly hands).
turn.12: physiologic, essential, epileptic, and symptomatic  Drugs used to treat palatal myoclonus include clonazepam, carbamazepine, baclofen, anticholinergics, tetrabenazine, valproic acid, phenytoin, lamotrigine, sumatriptan, and PIR
